text: A quick warning, there are curse words that are unbeeped in today's episode of the show.
If you prefer a beeped version, you can find that at our website, thisamericanlife.org.
Maybe you'll go to hard to remember now, but when Donald Trump announced he was officially
running for president again this time around, he did not say inevitable.
Far from it.
It was a week after the midterm elections where the Trumpiest candidates lost some key races.
The whole show governed around a Santa's beating him for the Republican nomination.
He had very few endorsements from other Republican politicians.
Jonathan Karl covered Trump's announcement for ABC News, where his chief Washington correspondent.
I was at Mar-a-Lago.
It was a really flat speech.
He was, first of all, it was teleprompter Trump.
He was reading from the teleprompter.
There was no fire in brimstone to it.
It was kind of warmed over policy proposals.
It was flat.
We will bring our supply chains and manufacturing base back home as we were strongly doing during
the Trump administration.
We will systematically bring Trump to the table.
People tried to leave the room.
I was there in Mar-a-Lago.
I saw people going to the exits halfway through the speech.
At one point, there were so many people leaving that they actually blocked the exits.
They told me it was for security reasons.
I don't think he wanted a half-empty Mar-a-Lago ballroom at the conclusion of his presidential
announcement.
So, not a great beginning.
When did it turn around?
Jonathan says that began with the speech that Trump gave a few months later in March
2023 at the annual CPAC conference, Conservatives.
It was a very different speech, with a very different tone.
It's really dark, and it is filled with talk about getting essentially revenge at those
who have wronged him.
Democrat prosecutors, oh, they're after me for so many things.
Oh, those prosecutors.
Some are racists.
Some hate our country.
They all hate me.
They'll get me for anything, anything.
You put a comma in this paragraph, why did you do that?
I don't really know.
This is the famous speech where he said, I am your retribution.
In 2016, I declared, I am your voice.
Today I add, I am your warrior.
I am your justice.
And for those who have been wronged and betrayed, I am your retribution.
I am your retribution.
Not that I'm wrong.
And that line obviously stuck out in the speech itself, but then speaking to Steve Bannon afterwards.
Steve Bannon, former Trump adviser, still apparently talks to him.
He said that was the pivotal moment in the campaign.
The campaign got its mojo, and he kept on calling it the come retribution speech.
Come retribution, Bannon explained to Jonathan, was referenced to a book about a supposed
plot by the Confederacy to kidnap and maybe kill Abraham Lincoln.
The plan was codenamed, come retribution, because it was revenge.
I don't think that Bannon's calling for the assassination of Trump's political opponents
or anything like that, but he is calling for, and Trump is calling for, an effort to get
even with these people to make them pay for their transgressions, their transgressions
being crossing Donald Trump.
Weeks after that speech, former President Trump held his very first official campaign
rally for the new campaign.
Kind of a big moment.
And it was not in the swing state.
There were any places he needed to pick up votes.
Location he chose?
Weco, Texas.
Now, I've been covering presidential campaigns for a long time and presidential announcements.
They often are, you know, weighted in symbolism, you know, Barack Obama and Springfield.
He decides to have it in Weiko, Texas.
Weiko, Texas, of course, is the place where the branch Davidians, David Kresh, had their
standoff with federal agents in 1993.
This was ended in disaster.
The place went up in flames.
Seventy-five people died.
It is the symbol for the far right of a government that is out of control and is a threat to
its own citizens.
So here is the place that Donald Trump goes to have his very first rally.
When I asked Bannon about it, I was like, come on, Weiko, what's going on here?
He said, what do you mean?
We are the Trump Davidians.
We laughed, but there was clearly a message being sent.
The federal government was out of control.
The deep state was out of control when the branch Davidians were raided and the result
was a bloodbath.
Once again, they are out of control.
This time they're going after Donald Trump and his MAGA supporters.
And what you saw on stage when the rally started, did it seem appropriate to the setting
and to that context?
It was so remarkable.
And a lot of people didn't really know it much because we're early in the presidential
campaign cycle long before people are actually going to be voting.
But it started with Donald Trump coming out on stage silently as the speaker started blaring
the national anthem performed by a group called the J6 Choir.
The J6 Choir being people who were in a DC prison for alleged crimes related to January
6, allegedly assaulting police officers breaking into the Capitol building.
And Trump, as this is playing out, is standing on stage, hand over his heart, and the scenes
on the screens behind Trump are the images of the assault on the US Capitol on January
Again, we're in Waco, Texas.
One nation, under God.
Donald Trump spoke for an hour and a half.
And most of it was the kind of stuff you'd expect.
How Joe Biden's running down the country.
How great things were when Trump was president.
He talked about inflation and China and the fake news media.
But over and over through the speech and in his speeches since he lectured about how the
government under Joe Biden is out to get you.
The Biden regime's weaponization of law enforcement against their political opponent is something
straight out of the Stalinist, Russia, horror show.
There'll be no doubt the injustice is being done, not only to me, but to dozens across
our country will not stand, or we're not going to stand for it.
It's the heart of a speech.
It's the core of his message.
The government is out of control.
It is out to get you.
I'm the guy standing in the way.
That's why I'm being prosecuted.
Prosecatorial misconduct is their new tool, and they are willing to use it at levels never
seen before.
The impression that people have is that Trump hasn't changed.
Yeah, he's outrageous.
Yeah, he does controversial stuff.
But that's actually not correct.
Trump has changed, at least the message.
This is a very different campaign.
This is not the campaign that got him elected to the White House in 2016, and it's not the
campaign that he waged in 2020.
This is different.
For those who have been wronged and betrayed, of which there are many people out there
that have been wronged and betrayed, I have your retribution.
We will take care of it.
We will take care of it.
This is something that Jonathan thinks lots of people might not have noticed so lately.
The degree to which Donald Trump's campaign this time around is about getting back at
his enemies.
Jonathan tries to capture this in his book about Trump, tired of winning.
Which is actually the inspiration for today's show.
What exactly might Donald Trump's revenge look like if he got back into office?
When some ways it's still hard to say, there's the best information out there on this.
Number one, on his agenda, for a long time.
It seems to be that it is going to go after other Republicans.
Specifically, people who have been his allies turned against him.
That's what we seem to be the most angry about.
We know this because people close to Trump told reporters like Isaac Arnstorff from Washington
Post that this is who we talked about going after.
Isaac heard the retribution speech.
And I didn't really think about it as a synonym for revenge until we were talking to people
who had heard Trump say privately, no actually like there are specific people who we are
going to punish for the crime of criticizing Donald Trump.
People like his former attorney general Bill Barr who called Trump's idea that the election
was stolen total nonsense.
Or the former chairman of the Joint Chiefs of Staff Mark Millie, they had a following
out.
In public, Trump talks about locking up Republicans like Liz Cheney, the top Republican in the
January 6 hearings.
And how could he do this?
Well, the second thing that we know about Donald Trump's retribution is that he's probably
going to use the Department of Justice to go after his enemies if he takes the White
House again.
Neither parts of government as well.
He tells people that's what he wants to do.
And also, people from his first administration have come forward.
He talked about how he wanted to do that during his first term in office, but he was stopped.
Trump's former attorney general Jeff Sessions, quoted in the Mueller report saying that Trump
asked him to authorize an investigation into Hillary Clinton.
His former chief of staff John Kelly told the New York Times about how, during his first
term, Trump asked him to sick the IRS on former FBI Director James Comey.
He told the Washington Post that Trump would often suggest using the Department of Justice
or the FBI to prosecute his political enemies.
Again, the Washington Post's Isaac Armstrong.
Kelly would just kind of say, yes sir, and then kind of sit on it until he forgot about
it and moved on.
Like, this is not a secret that Trump wanted to use power this way when he was president
the first time.
But Jeff Sessions didn't do it.
John Kelly didn't do it.
And, you know, guess what?
They are not going to be there in a second term.
Trump has told people that his biggest regret from his first term was appointing people
who told him no like that.
He's not going to do it again.
And the truth is, there's no law to stop any president from using the Department of Justice
to go after people this way.
It's just tradition, which brings me to number three, Democrats.
I know.
This one's not a surprise.
I will appoint a real special prosecutor to go after the most corrupt president and the
history of the United States of America, Joe Biden, and the entire Biden crime family.
And all others involved with the destruction of our elections, our borders, and our country
itself.
They're destroying our country.
And here's number four.
You know, when I'm real acting...
The target low-level government officials have stopped him in the past.
I will totally obliterate the deep state.
We will obliterate the deep state.
And we know who they are.
I know exactly who they are.
I'm trying to accomplish that in the last month's first term by changing the rules
within executive order so that he could fire civil servants who didn't do what he wanted.
When Joe Biden took office, Biden reversed that policy to what it was.
But it's been reported that Trump loyalists are planning to bring it back.
It was one more thing to keep in mind as we contemplate what retribution might mean
in a second Trump term.
And that's how Donald Trump and his allies see the powers of the president.
Trump's lawyers have been arguing lately in the Supreme Court, in the Georgia vote fraud
case, that the president has enormous latitude to use the arms of government to do whatever
he wants.
Much greater latitude than previous presidents have taken.
Trump's lawyers told the Supreme Court that if the president ordered the military to kill
a political opponent, in their view he could not be prosecuted for that as a crime.
The only people who could do anything about it is Congress.
And the only thing they can do is impeach him.
Over the past year, Donald Trump has gone through periods where he really was not talking about
retaliation that much.
But then a week ago, of course, he was found guilty on 34 felony counts in New York City
and retribution is back in force.
I mean, now he's been joined by an army of furious right wing commentators and politicians
who are demanding prosecutions and Democrats in retaliation for Trump's court cases.
If the Democrats are going to play this game, we've got to play the same.
We have to play by their rules.
Now, when are we going to start arresting Democrats?
That's what I want to know.
Republican AGs all over the country should pursue their own indictments.
Take corrupt Democrats, put them on trial in front of juries that already hate them before
the trial even begins.
Those are Todd Starrens on the Truth Network.
And Matt Walsh, who has nearly 3 million subscribers on YouTube, is Donald Trump Jr.
If we don't start fighting fire with fire, they're just going to keep doing it.
They'll take their wins and they'll laugh.
And when we do a banger, so you're threatening democracies.
Like, Luke, you're the ones literally trying to jail your political opposition.
So what we have this year is an unusual candidate who is promising something we have not seen
in a presidential candidate before.
That once he gets into office, he's going to take retribution on those who have opposed
him.
And he's telling us that he believes he has broad powers to command the Justice Department
and other branches of government to help him do that.
We want to take an hour to think about what that might look like.
And what it might mean for the people who are going to be most affected by it.
And that is, the people who've crossed him in the past, the people in his enemies list.
How seriously are they taking this?
After Donald Trump says a lot of shit that he never really delivers on.
He never fully built that wall with Mexico.
Mexico did not pay for any of it.
Never did a lock up Hillary Clinton.
We really tried.
As I speak these words, Trump is leading in three of the six swing states tied in the
other three.
Today we visit with a few of the people that Trump hates because they try to puzzle out
what Trump might do to them.
How do you plan for this?
We get a variety of answers.
WBEZ Chicago, it's this American life.
I'm out of glass.
Stay with us.
At one, Republicans who cross Trump.
So we're going to start today with two Republicans who are pretty worried about what Donald
Trump might do to them if he returns to office.
One of them was a diehard Trump loyalist.
One of them was a diehard Trump opponent.
At least we go visit with them.
Plainville, Kansas is a small town with less than 2,000 people.
The kind of place that feels very far away from the rest of the world, from its noise
and its concerns and its dangers, which I think is part of what attracted Stephanie
Grisham to the area.
See this lady right here?
A 70-ish year old woman in a colorful hat passes in front of Stephanie's car.
I really want to be her friend.
She's always dressed to the nines and goes to all the high school football games and
I just love her.
Stephanie moved here from DC four years ago.
Wow, this is a different scene, huh?
It's been a lot to get used to, but ma'am, I've sure grown to love it.
I really have.
Really?
Yeah.
Stephanie's previous scene was the White House.
She was one of the Trump staffers who lasted the longest.
She went to a Trump rally two weeks after his descent on the Golden Esquator and was
amazed by how he connected with the crowd.
She'd never seen anything like it.
So she signed up and lasted all the way until the storming of the Capitol on January 6th.
I was interested in talking with Stephanie because when she was with the Trumps, it was
actually part of her job to help them take retribution against their enemies.
Stephanie played a variety of roles for the Trumps.
She was Melania's chief of staff for a time, but she also worked at the highest levels
of the West Wing.
In fact, at one point, she was press secretary and director of communications for the White
House and was also responsible for communications for Melania.
P.S., she was the only White House press secretary to never hold a single press briefing.
But Stephanie says even outside of her formal White House jobs, she spent a huge amount
of time with the Trumps.
I would always go with them during all the holidays.
So I was at Mar-a-Lago with them for Christmas, New Year's, all the way to Easter.
So I was just always there.
Always there.
So literally in the room at so many critical moments.
Like on election night in 2020, it was Stephanie who tipped out into the first lady's bedroom
around one to waker.
So Melania would be dressed and ready to go on camera when Trump came out to speak.
As Melania got ready in the bathroom, Stephanie says that she sat with Barron at the end
of her bed watching television news and calling out the results so Melania would know which
states had been decided.
Really, Stephanie's been through all kinds of things with the Trumps.
I mean, there was the time he felt that he needed to tell me that Stormy Daniels was
wrong about his penis size.
So that was a really weird conversation.
And he called me from Air Force One, which made the whole conversation worse because there's
a tiny delay between the person on the plane and the person on the ground.
January 6 was the turning point for Stephanie.
She said she was horrified that Trump didn't immediately denounce the breach of the Capitol
and attacks on Mike Pence.
And when she reached out to Melania to ask her to intervene with her husband, Melania
said no.
For Stephanie, that was the last straw.
She told me she sent her resignation email about 15 minutes later.
But Stephanie didn't stop it resigning.
She also agreed to testify for the January 6th committee, spoke out against Donald Trump
on television, and wrote a tell-all book about her experience with the Trumps that became
a national bestseller.
From a Trump perspective, Stephanie says she's sinned in almost every possible way she could
sin.
And she's been clear from the beginning, literally from the moment she pressed to send on her
resignation email about what that would mean for her.
Oh, I knew I would be cast out.
I knew I would immediately be a traitor.
I mean, I helped do it to people.
If anybody spoke out against Mrs. Trump or the president, I was the one issuing terrible,
you know, statements calling them a liar, saying they were looking for fame.
Stephanie says that since she was a Trump true believer, she mostly felt fine about this.
She saw it as an important part of her job to push back.
But still, she says, there were some uncomfortable moments.
I called Mitt Romney a scum, I think.
And this is a man I had worked for and actually had really respected and was always really
kind when I ever passed by him.
And I remember right when the word scum came out of my mouth, I inside was like, oh, that
was way too far, way too far.
That was really harsh and that was pretty gross of me.
Of course, I get back to the White House and I got just praise from the president.
That was great.
You were so tough.
You're so tough, you know.
So then that makes you feel good because now the president is happy with you.
And that's one of the things about Donald Trump.
He doesn't give you a specific direction.
He just says, go after him.
And he leaves you to do the dirty work.
Stephanie says one of the only times Trump gave her very specific directions was after
John Kelly stepped down as chief of staff and then criticized Trump in the press.
Stephanie says at one point, Trump called her to say she needed to make a public statement
savaging Kelly who was a person Stephanie liked and respected.
He said that I needed to call this reporter and say, General Kelly doesn't understand
the genius of our great president.
And he said, take it down, take this down.
So I remember I wrote it down and I hung up the phone and I sat there and I remember
I called my boyfriend.
I called the one of the deputy chiefs of staff at the time and I think I called just like
my best friend and I knew I was like, oh my gosh, he wants me to say this is horrible,
right?
And everyone was like, yeah, that's really horrible.
And but I picked up the phone and I did it and it sounded like I worked for Kim Jong
like the genius of our great president who says that, but I did.
And so he called me later that day, the president and said, hey, I really that was great.
I really appreciate what you said.
That was really tough.
And I'm thinking you had me write that down like it was just very, very clear.
Stephanie says that Trump wanted you to be as ruthless as possible with his enemies.
She says Trump seemed to genuinely admire people who were ruthless.
I remember one specific time when he we were in a by-lat with President Erdogan of
Turkey and we were all sitting around this table.
I was I think maybe the only woman in the room, maybe a couple others, but out of the
blue, literally, he just yells down to me, Stephanie, who do you think is the biggest
killer?
This guy or president, she of China, he asked me that in a room of 30 to 40 people.
I'm supposed to decide who's the biggest murderer as if that's cool.
And I remember I just said, I don't know, this guy looks pretty tough, sir.
You laugh about it.
And I remember afterwards he came up to me and grabbed me out, grabbed my elbow and he goes,
hey, just so you know, it's president.
She, I've seen him do some shit.
And that was the moment that I was like, he really loves this.
He really loves.
He wanted to know who has murdered more of their own people, their own people.
Yeah.
Unfortunately for Stephanie, Donald Trump doesn't usually forget his grudges.
And maybe worse, it's not just Donald who's angry with her.
The worst part for me is that I'm on her radar.
So like a general Kelly is not on Melania Trump's radar.
So I've got like both of them.
And I know that she is very, very good at revenge as well.
And I want to be clear, Stephanie seems to genuinely care for her and in some ways even
admire Melania Trump.
Since she was Melania's chief of staff and communications director, they got to know each
other pretty well.
And you can tell when you read Stephanie's book that even now she has fond feelings for
her former boss, Mrs. or even.
But she's seen what Melania is capable of.
She says Melania's tried to use the government to go after enemies in the past.
She had a friend who kind of worked for her, Stephanie Winston-Wolkoff.
You also wrote a book about her while we were in the White House.
And when Stephanie's book came out, Melania wanted to sue her because that's what they
do, the Trump sue people.
And Melania's reasoning was she wanted to sue Stephanie for violating a non-disclosure
agreement that Stephanie had signed.
Well, we all signed.
But those had been deemed that they didn't really matter because we were for the government.
And Pat Sipolone, our attorney, our White House attorney kept telling Melania, no, if
you want to do this, you need to do it with your personal lawyer.
This isn't a government thing.
And Melania was like, nope, nope, I want to sue her.
I want to sue her.
And she forced Pat Sipolone to make the Justice Department take it on.
Pat said, two or three times this should be your personal lawyer.
This is not a government situation.
And she finally one day said, I don't care.
Do it.
So they did it.
I reached out to Pat Sipolone and the Justice Department to confirm Stephanie's story.
Neither would comment.
The Justice Department did file a suit against Stephanie Winston Wilkoff shortly after her
book came out.
The Biden administration dropped that suit, its first month in office.
But this story points to something that really worries Stephanie about a second Trump term.
She believes there will be many fewer Pat Sipolone's people willing to push back or say no to
the Trump's because like Ira mentioned earlier, Trump has told people he's not going to appoint
anyone this time around who will tell him no.
And there's something else that Stephanie is worried about in a second Trump term, something
I heard from a few people.
It's not how he'd use government institutions for personal retribution.
It's another weapon at his disposal.
He and she, they both can call forth these armies of people, mostly online, but certainly
we've seen with January 6 and other situations that some are in public.
And you just get besieged with hate and bullying and they know that and they wield that power
like no problem.
And I remember there were times with Mrs. Trump that I'd say, do you want me to put a statement
out about this person who said something bad about you?
And she'd say no, no, no, we will let all my fans get them.
And that meant the people online, you know, all her supporters would go after this person.
And they do.
The people I spoke to for this story told me that they feared Trump would encourage
a kind of culture of vengefulness in a second term.
And that Magazellitz might feel liberated to do what they want because Trump's government
will have their backs.
After all, he has already promised to pardon the January 6 rioters, which brings me to
Fred Wellman and the way that fear of retribution from Trump supporters can infect a life.
Fred lives in a suburb of St. Louis on this residential street with modest houses.
And he told me that a couple months ago, right before bed, he let his dog river out for her
bedtime stretch.
You know, open the door.
She jumps down three steps and sitting right here with those garbage cans are was a pickup
truck sitting there idling facing my house and I'm like, okay, I washed up for a second.
Couldn't see tended windows.
Couldn't see what's going on.
I'm like, that's strange.
You're talking 10 o'clock at night?
What got me gone was I gave him bug eyes.
You know, I looked at him.
I gave him stink eyes like, what are you doing here?
It's looked and you know, he had to know I saw him and I came back and they didn't leave,
which is really suspicious.
And in your mind, what was the first thought you had about who could be sitting in that
truck?
Uh, Trump supporters, MAGA, MAGA, MAGA extremists, if you will.
I'm on the list.
I'm on the list.
And what do you mean by list?
Oh, enemies.
I'm on the MAG enemies list.
To be clear, it's not a literal list, but Fred's definitely done enough to get on the
wrong side of Trump world.
Fred Woods, executive director of The Lincoln Project.
Maybe you've heard of it.
It's this group of high profile Republican operatives who set out to use their political
know-how to keep Trump out of power in 2020 and immediately attracted attention and money.
The group trolled Trump on Twitter daily and spent close to $80 million on a series
of viral anti-Trump campaign ads.
Trump responded with rage tweets.
There were a bunch.
And those written attacks from Trump almost immediately translated into actual attacks
from Trump supporters.
One Lincoln Project founder I talked to said that hundreds of boxes of excrement were
mailed to his house.
Then a couple months ago, Fred discovered that all of his information and the information
of his family members had been posted on this doxing site that he didn't want to name,
but which he showed me during our visit.
I keep it open.
I love the picture of the devil.
It's very subtle.
There it is.
That's my stepson.
That's my dad who's dead.
That's my ex-wife's ex-husband.
That's my brother.
That's my mother.
They do have all the email and socials, right?
They have all your email.
Yeah, but that's not me.
I guess just a Fred Wellman was a realtor.
They keep mistaking for me.
Poor friend.
Well, I know.
Have you reached out to him and be like, sorry guy?
You should change his name.
I was first.
At the top of the page was a box which listed how many people had searched for Fred's name.
There were 187.
And now this truck was sitting near his driveway.
Could it be a Trump supporter?
So anyway, I do what I do, which is, you know...
Just explain what this is.
I have a 9mm handgun, Smith & Wesson 9mm.
In the drawer by your bev?
Yeah.
Or actually on the nightstand.
Before getting sideways with Trump World, Fred didn't keep guns in his house, much less
on his bedside table.
It's not that Fred's uncomfortable with guns.
Fred's military.
You went to West Point, was a protégé of David Petraeus, served in Desert Storm, and
had three combat tours in Iraq.
It's just that after his time in the military, Fred struggled very seriously with PTSD.
And so to be saved, about seven years ago, he got rid of all of his weapons.
He told me it was the responsible thing to do for his kids, for his family.
Easy access to guns kills veterans.
So it was a big deal for me to go ahead and get one.
Did you have...
Is it okay for me to ask?
Did you at a certain point have real trouble with suicidal ideas?
Oh yeah.
Oh yeah.
That was a constant companion to me for many years.
Many, many years.
But I went to treatment for PTSD back in 2018 as my wife and I separated.
And I took that.
And I still still therapy, still treating it.
Come a long way.
That's why Fred swore off guns.
At least until he was promoted to executive director of the Lincoln Project in 2021.
MAGA supporters already hated them.
But on his first day on the job, something happened that unleashed a whole new level
of fury at the group.
One of the Lincoln Project's founders admitted to sending sexually suggestive messages to
young men, which turned MAGA's anger at the group up to 11.
The daily barrage was so extreme, the professional security consultants hired to do a threat
analysis told Fred and his colleagues to avoid going outside.
Fred felt he had no choice.
He said he drove to a store and purchased the Smith & Wesson, carried it everywhere,
even inside his house.
I need to have it in the same room just to make sure in case somebody kicked the door
in or came in the back door that I'd least be able to fight back.
I had a whole plan where I'd fall back.
What's safe for him?
I set up a safe room.
I mean, just put my extra ammo in the bathroom upstairs so I had to retreat.
If I had to retreat to the bathroom, I'd have the extra ammo in the bathroom.
I mean, it was pretty intense for a while there.
Again, I'm an old soldier.
I'm not going to sit back and let him kill me.
Being aware of my surroundings, being aware of my operations security is my way of life
now.
It has to be.
You know, I have a choice.
Which brings me back to that night in late January and the truck parked in front of Fred's
driveway.
Fred told me he peeked through the blinds with a gun in his hand, waiting until eventually
it drove away.
At the time, did you question, am I being paranoid?
Oh, yeah, I always do.
You always do.
I mean, why wouldn't you?
You know, it's a weird thing to think something might want to.
You know, it's just, it's so ridiculous.
The idea even, even somebody who lives this life is wondering, you know, am I just being
ridiculous?
You know, I always question that.
Does it bother you to think that you're paranoid?
Yeah, it does.
But that's the goal, right?
I mean, the goal, I think, for all these guys is to make us on edge, that to, to wear
us out to make you quit, to say, you know what?
This is too much heat.
This is too much danger for me.
And I have peers who have done that.
I have peers who have backed out of their op, you know, quieted down or gone to other
things.
